May 14, 1978: Fiction
BLOODLINE, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $9.95.) Love and high financial
intrigue on three continents.
THE HOLCROFT COVENANT, by Robert Ludlum. (Putnam's/Richard Marek,
$10.95.) Nazi scheme to found a Fourth Reich.
SCRUPLES, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $10.) Woman's rise in the fashion world.
THE THORN BIRDS, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $9.95.) Australian
family saga.
THE SILMARILLION, by J.R.R. Tolkien. (Houghton Mifflin, $10.95.) Middle Earth
in pre-Hobbit days.
THE HUMAN FACTOR, by Graham Greene. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Spy
novel with the Greene touch.
WHISTLE, by James Jones. (Delacorte, $10.95.) Final Volume of Jones's World
War II trilogy; honest and moving.
A STRANGER IS WATCHING, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $8.95.)
Random killer at large in the city.
THE PLAGUE DOGS, by Richard Adams. (Knopf, $10.95.) Cops and
dogknappers in Southern California.
ILLUSIONS, by Richard Bach. (Delacorte/Eleanor Friede, $5.95.) Messiah
barnstorms Middle America.
THE WOMEN'S ROOM, by Marilyn French. (Summit Books, $10.95.) Woman's
rough road to liberation.
THE LAST CONVERTIBLE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $10.95.) Five Harvard
classmates through World War II to middle age.
RACHEL, THE RABBI'S WIFE, by Sylvia Tenenbaum. (Morrow, $9.95.) Keeping
the faith in suburbia.
THE HONORABLE SCHOOLBOY, by John le Carr√©. (Knopf, $10.) Espionage in
Hong Kong.
GOODBYE CALIFORNIA, by Allistair MacLean. (Doubleday, $8.95.) Muslim plot
to heave the state into the sea.
Non-Fiction
THE COMPLETE BOOK OF RUNNING, by James F. Fixx. (Random House, $10.)
For fun and health.
IF LIFE IS A BOWL OF CHERRIES -- WHAT AM I DOING IN THE PITS?  by
Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $7.95.) More domestic drolleries.
MY MOTHER/MY SELF, by Nancy Friday. (Delacorte, $9.95.) A study of the
mother and daughter relationship.
ADRIEN ARPEL'S THREE-WEEK CRASH MAKEOVER, SHAPEOVER BEAUTY
PROGRAM, by Adrien Arpel. (Antheneum, $11.95.) Advice from the head of an
international cosmetics corporation.
GNOMES, text by Wil Huygen, illustrated by Rien Poortvliet. (Harry N. Abrams,
$14.95.) Everything you wanted to know about the little people.
THE AMITYVILLE HORROR, by Jay Anson. (Prentice-Hall, $7.95.) Haunted
house in suburbia.
ALL THINGS WISE AND WONDERFUL, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's Press,
$10.) More adventures of a Yorkshire vet.
THE ONLY INVESTMENT GUIDE YOU'LL EVER NEED, by Andrew Tobias.
(Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $5.95.) Written with a sense of humor.
PULLING YOUR OWN STRINGS, by Wayne W. Dyer. (Funk & Wagnalls, $8.95.)
Taking charge of your life.
THE FINAL CONCLAVE, by Malachi Martin. (Stein & Day, $11.95.) Communists
will influence choice of the next Pope.
LOOKING OUT FOR NUMBER ONE, by Robert Ringer. (Cromwell, $9.95.) How
to get yours.
THE ENDS OF POWER, by H.R. Halderman with Joseph DiMona. (Times Books,
$12.95.) Watergate, etc. by the former Presidential aide.
COMING INTO THE COUNTRY, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$10.95.) The last of the big country - Alaska.
IN HIS IMAGE: The Cloning of a Man, by David M. Rorvik. (Lippincolt, $8.95.)
Wealthy man reproduces himself.
DESIGNING YOUR FACE, by Way Bandy. (Random House, $8.95.) How to use
cosmetics.
